content.text:
When an unsymmetrical alkene such as propene is treated with N-bromosuccinimide in aqueous dimethyl sulfoxide, the major product has the bromine atom bonded to the less highly substituted carbon atom. Is the following one Markovnikov or non-Markovnikov orientation? <image 1>

A. Markovnikov orientation.
B. Non-Markovnikov orientation.
C. Non of the above.

To determine whether the reaction follows Markovnikov's rule or not, we need to understand the orientation of the addition of the bromine and hydroxyl groups to the alkene.

Markovnikov's rule states that when an unsymmetrical reagent adds to an alkene, the positive part of the reagent (usually a hydrogen) adds to the carbon with more hydrogen atoms (the more substituted carbon), while the negative part (usually a halogen or a hydroxyl group) adds to the carbon with fewer hydrogen atoms (the less substituted carbon).

In the given reaction:
\[ \text{CH}_3\text{CH}=\text{CH}_2 + \text{Br}_2, \text{H}_2\text{O} \rightarrow \text{CH}_3\text{CHCH}_2\text{Br} \]

The bromine atom is bonded to the less substituted carbon (the middle carbon), and the hydroxyl group is bonded to the more substituted carbon (the rightmost carbon). This is consistent with Markovnikov's rule.

Therefore, the correct answer is:

A. Markovnikov orientation.
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
